title: 112_s3267
content: The Act is titled the "American Opportunity Tax Credit Permanence and Consolidation Act of 2012." It extends and modifies the American Opportunity Tax Credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The American Opportunity Tax Credit allows eligible students to receive a credit against their tax for tuition expenses up to $2,000 if enrolled at least half-time. The tax credit allows eligible students to receive a credit for tuition expenses up to $2,000, plus 25% of expenses exceeding $2,000 but not exceeding $6,000. For other students, the credit is 30% of qualified tuition expenses up to $10,000. There are limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for tuition expenses is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The reduction amount is calculated based on specific income thresholds for single and joint filers. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit cannot exceed the sum of the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55, minus the total of other allowable credits for the taxable year. The tax credit for tuition expenses is subject to limitations. The aggregate amount of credits claimed for all taxable years cannot exceed $15,000. No credit is allowed unless the taxpayer reports the qualified tuition and related expenses of an eligible student. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited to $15,000 in total credits claimed for all taxable years. To claim the credit, the taxpayer must report the qualified tuition and related expenses of an eligible student on their tax return. Additionally, the amount of qualified tuition and related expenses may be reduced by certain scholarships or educational assistance allowances. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited to $15,000 in total credits claimed for all taxable years. It includes educational assistance allowances under specific chapters of the United States Code and payments for educational expenses that are excludable from gross income. Coordination with Pell Grants not used for qualified tuition and related expenses is also mentioned. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited to $15,000 in total credits claimed for all taxable years. Expenses attributable to a Federal Pell Grant shall be reduced by the amount of expenses not considered qualified tuition and related expenses for determining the cost of attendance at an eligible educational institution. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited to $15,000 in total credits claimed for all taxable years. Expenses paid by a dependent individual may be treated as paid by another taxpayer if a deduction is allowed for the dependent. Qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the dependent during their taxable year shall be treated as paid by the other taxpayer. For an academic period starting within the first 3 months after the taxable year, it is considered to begin in that year. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for both credit and deduction. Married individuals must file jointly for the credit. Nonresident aliens must be treated as residents for the credit to apply. The section applies if an individual is a resident alien of the US due to an election under subsection (g) or (h) of section 6013. A taxpayer can elect not to apply this section to qualified tuition expenses. An eligible student is someone enrolled in an eligible educational institution meeting specific requirements. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Permanence and Consolidation Act of 2012 defines qualified tuition and related expenses as tuition, fees, and course materials required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Permanence and Consolidation Act of 2012 defines qualified tuition and related expenses as expenses for education at an eligible institution, excluding sports, games, hobbies, nonacademic fees, and including computer technology and equipment. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Permanence and Consolidation Act of 2012 specifies that eligible educational institutions must meet certain criteria and allows for a portion of the credit to be refundable. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Permanence and Consolidation Act of 2012 allows for certain credits to be treated as a credit under subpart C, with exceptions for taxpayers who are children under subsection (g) of section 1. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for recapture of the credit in cases of refunds in subsequent taxable years. The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to update references to the American Opportunity Tax Credit. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to update references to the American Opportunity Tax Credit, including changes to section 221(d), section 222(d), and section 529(c)(3)(B) of the Code. Amendments are made to update references to the American Opportunity Tax Credit in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes changes to section 529(e)(3)(B), section 530(d)(2), and section 530(d)(4)(B) of the Code. Amendments are made to update references to the American Opportunity Tax Credit in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to section 530(d)(4)(B), section 904(i), section 1400C(d)(2), section 1400O, and section 6050S(e). Amendments were made to update references to the American Opportunity Tax Credit in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The changes include updating subsections in sections 6050S, 6211, and 6213 of the Code. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The amendment expands the Pell Grant exclusion from gross income for qualified tuition and related expenses. It applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
